Introduction Draft
If you take any English class, you will be asked to write an argument or persuasive essay. This task asks that you choose a controversial topic, take a position or give an informed opinion on the issue, and then convince your audience or reader that you have a valid opinion. Traditionally, students learn that an argument is war. Applying this metaphor, they see anyone who does not agree with their point as an enemy. They challenge and attack the opponent’s claims while aggressively defending their own. Next, they target the indefensible weak points, and then they counterattack and shoot down those claims in order to maim or kill the assertions made by the enemy. Often, they use fighting words to defend their position on the topic so that by the end of the essay, the audience is left with the memory of a vicious verbal battle. Please, stop the nonsense! Let us be more civilized. The best argument essays are like a dance in which the writer takes the lead and guides the audience to see his position as a valid one.
